Award.AwardTitle: NCAR Activities supported by the Naval Research Laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration: The DEEPWAVE (DEEP propagating gravity WAVE) experiment will observe one of the most dynamically active regions on Earth in terms of gravity wave (GW) forcing, deep upward GW propagation, and overall effects throughout the lower atmosphere, stratosphere and MLT. The program will use the NSF/NCAR GV, HAIS instruments, dropsondes and ISS to attempt to follow deeply propagating GWs from their tropospheric source to their mesospheric breakdown, and to pursue the scientific objectives of understanding deep GW propagation and testing new GW observing systems. Other NRL Activities will be support under this Cooperative Support Agreement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was an international, multi-agency collaboration, sponsored by the National Science Foundation and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory and included collaboration between the National Center for Atmospheric Research/Earth Observing Laboratory, Boston University, Utah State University, Yale University, GATS Inc. (US); National Institute of Water & Atmospheric Research, Met Service (New Zealand); DLR - Institut für Physik der Atmosphäre (Germany); and the Australian Government.

The DEEPWAVE (DEEP propagating gravity WAVE) experiment observed one of the most dynamically active regions on Earth in terms of gravity wave (GW) forcing, deep upward GW propagation, and overall effects throughout the lower atmosphere, stratosphere and mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT). The field campaign took place in Christchurch, New Zealand; South Island, New Zealand; and surrounding Southern Ocean, from May 29, 2014 to July 27, 2014.

The program used the NSF/NCAR GV, HAIS instruments, dropsondes and ISS to attempt to follow deeply propagating GWs from their tropospheric source to their mesospheric breakdown, and to pursue the scientific objectives of understanding deep GW propagation and testing new GW observing systems.  The NSF/NCAR GV aircraft was flown for a total of 183 hours in support of this field campaign.

The project examined how tropospheric winds and storms modulate the generation of gravity waves (GWs), how GWs propagate across the tropopause into the stratosphere, and how the Polar Night Jet and tidal winds influence GW propagation and breakdown in the middle atmosphere. Important observational components of DEEPWAVE included in situ measurement from the NSF/NCAR Gulfstream-V research aircraft along with surface, airborne and satellite-based remote sensing. Earth Observing Laboratory at NCAR also deployed an Integrated Sounding System (ISS) with a radar wind profiler and other ground instrumentation on the West Coast of New Zealand.

The study contributed to improved understanding, modeling, and parameterization of atmospheric gravity waves (GWs) by observing and characterizing them over their entire life cycle (0-100 km altitude) in localized “hotspot” regions identified in the satellite record.

The project provided significant training opportunities for a wide range of audiences, including scientists and the public. Educational Resources are documented at the following website: https://www.eol.ucar.edu/content/deepwave-educational-resources
